bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Rupert Blue, March 1, 1915

div1.p: Carter discusses legislation designed to inhibit mosquito breeding.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Rupert Blue, March 1, 1915
div1.opener:
Preparation of Sites of Ponds to
prevent their causing Malaria.
H. R. Carter, Senior Surgeon.
Legislation
March 1, 1915.
Surgeon-General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I would respectfully invite the attention of the Bureau to
the following:

The construction of hydro-electric plants in the malarious
section of the United States is increasing. There have been many
complaints of malarial fevers produced by the ponds of such plants
from communities adjacent thereto, as well as a number of suits for
damages on this account. Without attempting to pronounce on the
reasonableness of such complaints in any special case it is evident
that the construction of such ponds must affect the malarial situa-
tion of their environment and will increase malaria in some places
and diminish it in others.

The investigation of this subject begun by the Service, al-
though far from complete, is now in such a state that a malarial sur-
vey of the area to be covered by such a pond will enable us to devise
measures to be taken before the pond is filled which will greatly
lessen the breeding of mosquitoes and production of malaria--possibly
minimize them. This is only possible after a survey of the pond area
and its environment. The investigation has not sufficiently advanced
to allow us to formulate general rulesmeasures for ponds which would be within
-2-
the limits of allowable expenditure.

It is suggested, then, that the State Health Authorities re-
quire that before a pond is made a topographical map of the area to
be covered by the pond and adjacent country and such other data about
the pond as are pertinent be submitted to them and that the water be
not turned on until a permit to do so be given by them. This will
enable them to require the measures spoken of above to lessen the pro-
duction of malaria--or of mosquitoes.

While, of course, the primary consideration for this measure
is the prevention of conditions producing malaria, it will, in my
judgement, be of advantage--of great advantage--to the Power Companies
also in lessening the number of suits brought against them for produc-
ing such conditions.

It is not pretended that within the limits of allowable cost
the pond can be prevented from breeding mosquitoes and producing mala-
ria at every point; but this can be minimized by measures adapted to
the local conditions and within the economic limit.

I have only considered large ponds in this letter, but the
same principles apply to all ponds and there is no reason why a permit
should not be required for their construction also.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, H. R. Carter
Senior Surgeon. HRC/LC
